case_name: State v. Jagatsingh and Sheikh Ahmed

facts.text: Criminal Appeal 183 of 1961 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 17, 1960, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 2 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal 183 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 17, 1960, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 2 of 1959. R. Khanna and R. H. Dhebar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Dongarsing, a discharged truck driver from the army, was in need of employment and made an application to the District Soldiers Board, Dhulia towards the end of October 1955 praying for help in securing employment.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case briefly was that one Dongarsing, a discharged truck driver from the army, was in need of employment. Towards the end of October 1955 he made an application to the District Soldiers Board, Dhulia praying for help in securing employment.

facts.text: Dongarsing's application was forwarded to the Divisional Controller of the State Transport Corporation at Dhulia and he was asked to make a formal application on a printed form obtained on payment of As. 0-2-0.

anchor.surface_text: This application was forwarded to the Divisional Controller of the State Transport Corporation at Dhulia and Dongarsing was asked by the Corporation to make a formal application on a printed form to be obtained on payment of As. 0-2-0.

facts.text: Dongarsing applied for and received a printed form on November 19, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly Dongarsing applied for a printed form sometime in November 1955 which he received on November 19, 1955.

facts.text: Dongarsing met Sheikh Ahmed (respondent No. 2), who was in service in the department at Jamner, and asked him for help.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Dongar singh met Sheikh Ahmed  respondent No. 2  who was in service in the said department at jamner and asked him for help.

facts.text: Sheikh Ahmed told Dongarsing that Jagatsing (respondent No. 1), an officer in the State Transport Corporation at Dhulia, would secure a job for Dongarsing provided he was paid money.

anchor.surface_text: Sheikh Ahmed told Dongarsing that jagatsing  respondent No. 1  who was an officer in the State Transport Corporation at Dhulia would be able to secure a job for Dongarsing provided he was paid money.

facts.text: Dongarsing went to Dhulia with Sheikh Ahmed, met Jagatsing, and settled to pay Rs. 50 as bribe for securing the job of a driver on November 25, 1955; Rs. 25 paid immediately, remaining Rs. 25 paid about December 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, Dongarsing went to Dhulia along with Sheikh Ahmed and met jagatsing and it was settled that Dongarsing would pay Rs. 50.00 as bribe to Jagatsingh for securing the job of a driver. Rs. 25.00 were immediately paid on that very day namely November 25,.1955 and the remaining amount of Rs. 25.00 was paid a fortnight later about December 9, 1955.

facts.text: Dongarsing was informed at the end of January or beginning of February 1956 that his application for the post of driver had been rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Dongarsing was informed sometime at the end of January or beginning of February 1956 that his application for the post of driver had been rejected.

facts.text: Dongarsing approached Jagatsing again, who said he could not return Rs. 50 as it was paid to others but if another Rs. 50 paid, he might procure the job; another form procured and filled.

anchor.surface_text: He then went to Jagatsingh again and asked him to return the sum of Rs. 50- 00 already paid or secure the job for him. jagatsingh replied that he companyld number return the money as it had already been, paid to other persons but said that if he paid another Rs. 50.00 jagatsingh might be able to procure the job for him. So another printed form of application was procured by Jagatsingh and Dongarsing filled it up and gave it to Jagatsingh.

facts.text: Dongarsing approached the anti-corruption department, a trap was laid, and Rs. 30 in currency notes treated with anthracene powder were given to Dongarsing.

anchor.surface_text: By this time how- ever Dongarsing had become suspicious of the bona fides of jagatsingh and he therefore approached the anti-corruption department. So a trap was laid for catching Jagatsingh and Rs. 30.00 in currency numberes were given to Dongarsing for passing on to jagatsing after applying anthracene powder to them.

facts.text: On February 20, 1956 at about 3 p.m., Dongarsing passed Rs. 30 to Jagatsing, who had the money in hands but threw it down; particles of anthracene powder found on Jagatsing's thumb, two fingers, and seam of right pocket.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually on February 20, 1956, this amount of Rs. 30.00 was passed on by Dongarsingh to Jagatsing at about 3 p.m. After the money was paid the police caught jagatsingh who had the money in his hands but threw it down on being challenged. It was however found that particles of anthracene powder were on the thumb and two fingers of jagatsing and also on the seam of the right pocket of the pant of his trousers.

facts.text: Currency notes picked up, panchnama prepared, investigation done, Jagatsing and Sheikh Ahmed prosecuted.

anchor.surface_text: The currency numberes were then picked up and the necessary panchnama was prepared and after further investigation jagatsingh and Sheikh Ahmed were I prosecuted.

facts.text: Jagatsing denied guilt, said he had nothing to do with appointment of drivers and conductors and was never in position to do anything for Dongarsing.

anchor.surface_text: jagatsingh denied his guilt and said that he had numberhing to do with the appointment of drivers and companyductors and was never in a position to do anything for Dongarsing.

facts.text: Sheikh Ahmed denied guilt, said he only helped Dongarsing fill printed form but never told him to pay bribe to Jagatsing.

anchor.surface_text: Sheikh Ahmed also denied his guilt and said that all that he did was to help Dongarsing in filling up the printed form but that he never told Dongarsing that he had to pay a bribe to Jagatsingh in order to get the job.

facts.text: Trial court found prosecution proved case beyond reasonable doubt that Jagatsing accepted Rs.30 on Feb 20 as illegal gratification but held not safe for Sheikh Ahmed re earlier payments as accomplice, and Jagatsing not public servant u/s 43 Transport Act; acquitted both.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt found on the facts that the prosecution had proved its case beyond reasonable doubt and that Jagatsingh had accepted the currency numberes which Dongarsing gave him on February 20 as illegal gratification as a motive for securing the job for Dongarsing. As to Sheikh Ahmed the trial companyrt held that it would number be safe to accept the testimony of Dongarsing as to the payment of the two sums of money of Rs. 25.00 in November and December 1955 as he was an accomplice.

facts.text: State appealed to Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 2 of 1959; HC accepted finding of payment of Rs.30 to Jagatsing as bribe.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by an appeal by the State to the High Court of Bombay. The High Court apparently accepted the finding of the trial companyrt as to the payment of Rs. 30.00 as bribe to jagatsingh.

facts.text: Bombay HC acquitted respondents relying on State of Ajmer v. Shivjilal, holding no averment as to public servant to be approached.

anchor.surface_text: Relying on the judgment of this Court in State of Ajmer v. Shivjilal 1 , the High Court held that as there was numberaver- ment as to the public servant who was to be approached either in the companyplaint or in the evidence, it had numberoption but to companyfirm the acquittal ordered by the Special judge in view of Shivjilals case 1 .

facts.text: It is not in dispute that Jagatsing was an employee in the very office which would make the appointment of the driver.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that Jagatsingh was an employ in the very office which would make the appointment of the driver for which, job Dongarsing had applied.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that Shivjilal case does not apply as different part of s.161 applies; Jagatsing took money for official act in his office.

anchor.surface_text: In  such s. case we are of opinion that another part of s. 161 would apply which  again omitting the unnecessary words  reads as follows - Whoever, being a public servant, accepts or obtains, or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain from any person for himself or for any other person, any gratification whatever, other than legal remuneration, as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act or for showing or forbearing to show, in the exercise of his official functions, favour or disfavour to any person

facts.text: Jagatsing was a senior assistant in the traffic section in the Corporation at Dhulia.

anchor.surface_text: He was however a senior assistant in the traffic section in the companyporation at Dhulia thus even if he was number directly in a position to make the appointment himself that would number in our opinion make any difference to his guilt if he took the money

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Jagatsing not a public servant u/s 21 IPC read with s.43 Transport Act because taking bribe not acting or purporting to act in pursuance of provisions of Act; acquits both.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore when he took this money from Dongarsing he companyld number be said to be acting or purporting to act in pursuance of any of the provisions of the Transport Act or of any other law. Therefore he companyld number be a public servant within the language of s. 43

facts.text: Trial court acquitted Jagatsing on ground he was not a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the trial companyrt was right in acquitting Jagatsingh on the ground that he was number a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: We must say with respect that the High Court has read more in the decision in Shivjilals case 1 than what was decided therein. In that case the bribe was said to have been given to Shivjilal who was a teacher in a railway school at Phulera.

issues.text: whether taking of bribe is acting or purporting to act in pursuance of the provisions of the Transport Act or of any other law

anchor.surface_text: The difficulty is created by these words and the argument on behalf of the respondents is that the effect of these words in s. 43 is that all officers and servants of a corporation are public servants only when they are acting or purporting to act in pursuance of any of the provisions of the Transport Act or of any other law, and that taking of bribe is not acting or purporting to act in pursuance of any of the provisions of the Act or of any other law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unfortunate result but words of s.43 clear; legislature intended PS status only when acting/purporting under Act.

arguments.claim: s.43 words clear: PS only when acting/purporting under Act; obviated by later s.21 amendment but not applicable here.

anchor.surface_text: But the words are clear and it seems that members, officers and servants of the companyporation were intended by the legislature to be public servants only when they were acting or purporting to act in pursuance of the provisions of the Transport Act or of any other law and number otherwise.

holdings.text: The decision in Shivjilal's case does not apply to the facts of the present case because it concerned the first part of s.161 IPC where gratification is for rendering service to another public servant, whereas here the accused took money for an official act in his own office.

anchor.surface_text: We must say with respect that the High Court has read more in the decision in Shivjilals case 1 than what was decided therein. In that case the bribe was said to have been given to Shivjilal who was a teacher in a railway school at Phulera.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Shivjilal on facts (bribe for service to distant other PS) and applicable limb of s.161; no need to specify other PS here.

holdings.text: Omission to specify the other public servant in the charge under the first part of s.161 is a curable defect under s.537 CrPC unless it occasions failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: At the same time this Court did not lay down in Shivjilals case 1 that if the other public servant is not specified in the charge, the trial would be bad. Where the public servant is not specified in the charge that would only mean that there is defect in the charge and such a defect would be curable under s. 537 of the Code of Criminal Procedure unless such error or omission

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarifies Shivjilal did not hold trial vitiated per se; applies s.537 curative provision.

holdings.text: The facts fall under the second part of s.161 IPC: public servant accepting gratification as motive or reward for doing official act or showing favour in exercise of official functions.

anchor.surface_text: In such a case we are of opinion that another part of s. 161 would apply which again omitting the unnecessary words reads as follows - Whoever, being a public servant, accepts or obtains, or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain from any person for himself or for any other person, any gratification whatever, other than legal remuneration, as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual application of s.161 second limb to facts where accused in same office promising official act (appointment).

holdings.text: Even if not directly empowered to appoint, a senior assistant in traffic section taking money to procure appointment in his office incurs liability under s.161 as for himself or other person.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that Jagatsingh in his statement said that he had no concern with appointment of drivers and conductors and was not in a position to do anything for Dongarsing in the matter of securing employment for him. He was however a senior assistant in the traffic section in the corporation at Dhulia thus even if he was not directly in a position to make the appointment himself that would not in our opinion make any difference to his guilt if he took the money

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.161 covers gratification for official act by self or other in office; position enables influence.

holdings.text: Receiving bribe cannot be brought within acting or purporting to act in pursuance of Transport Act or other law; analogous to no sanction needed under s.197 CrPC for s.161.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether sanction of the Government was required under s. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure where any public servant is accused of an offence alleged to have been committed by him while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty came up for consideration by the Privy Council in cases under ss. 161 and 409 of the Indian Penal Code against public servants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent analogy from s.197 cases (Gill, Hori Ram); bribe not official duty.

holdings.text: Jagatsing not a public servant within s.21 IPC read with s.43 Transport Act as taking money from Dongarsing not acting or purporting to act in pursuance of Act.

anchor.surface_text: the argument on behalf of the respondents is that the effect of these words in s. 43 is that all officers and servants of a corporation are public servants only when they are acting or purporting to act in pursuance of any of the provisions of the Transport Act or of any other law, and that taking of bribe is not acting or purporting to act in pursuance of any of the provisions of the Act or of any other law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict textual reading of qualifying words in s.43; bribe unrelated to pursuance of Act.

holdings.text: Officers and servants of corporation deemed public servants u/s.43 only when acting or purporting to act in pursuance of Transport Act or other law, and not otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: But the words are clear and it seems that members, officers and servants of the corporation were intended by the legislature to be public servants only when they were acting or purporting to act in pursuance of the provisions of the Transport Act or of any other law and not otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative intent from clear words despite policy arguments against.

holdings.text: Trial court was right in acquitting Jagatsingh on ground he was not a public servant; Sheikh Ahmed also acquitted as no abetment without principal offence.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the trial court was right in acquitting Jagatsingh on the ground that he was not a public servant. It follows therefrom that Sheikh Ahmed must be acquitted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower court on s.43 interpretation; consequential acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that Jagatsingh in his statement said that he had no concern with appointment of drivers and conductors and was not in a position to do anything for Dongarsing in the matter of securing employment for him. anchor.surface_text: The question whether sanction of the Government was required under s. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure where any public servant is accused of an offence alleged to have been committed by him while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty came up for consideration by the Privy Council in cases under ss. 161 and 409 of the Indian Penal Code against public servants.

The question whether sanction of the Government was required under s. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure where any public servant is accused of an offence alleged to have been committed by him while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty came up for consideration by the Privy Council in cases under ss. 161 and 409 of the Indian Penal Code against public servants.
